topic.title: Rework of the plugin AnnounceShare + new plugin TrackerList
topic.body:
## AnnounceShare

https://github.com/geekless/ZeroNet/tree/AnnounceShare-rework

* Allow sharing trackers of any supported protocols, not just `zero://`. (Right now it includes BitTorrent over HTTP(S) and BitTorrent over UDP.)
  * The supported protocols are autodetected, not hardcoded, so the modification of the plugin is not required in the case of implementation of new protocols.
* Working trackers are now counted on per protocol basis. The plugin tries to maintain the up-to-date list of functional trackers for each available protocol.
* Be more conservative on removal trackers from the list. Don't delete trackers on errors if no successful connections have been established recently, in the case of the network connectivity issues.
* Other small code refactorings.

## TrackerList

https://github.com/geekless/ZeroNet/tree/TrackerList

(The plugin is disabled by default in the source tree. Should be enabled manually before running ZeroNet. The branch also contains the updated AnnounceShare, no additional merging is required.)

TrackerList is a plugin, that fetches a list of trackers from any external source (URL or local file path) and adds them info the AnnounceShare list. If the trackers are functional, AnnounceShare spreads them throughout the network to other peers.

By default, it fetches the data from https://github.com/ngosang/trackerslist.

The reworked AnnounceShare is required for TrackerList to work. It is also required on a peer, looking for new trackers, in order to be able to receive non-`zero://` trackers. (The old AnnounceShare forbids other tracker protocols.)

Please test and report any issues.

## UPDATE:

AnnounceShare will be forked and renamed to TrackerShare.

TrackerShare, TrackerList, gitcenter's PeerMessage and BackgroundProcessing will be packed together with the core and provided as a preconfigured distribution. A least, it will be available as a source archive and a docker image for Linux. (A bundle for Windows is possible too.)

Two more plugins are in development by me now as well.

topic.title: The centralized parts of ZeroNet
topic.body:
.
### ZeroID

Currently, there seems to be no reliable solution for that. My drafts: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1BLoGBTid3NhGu8ts3fAfHJprnbrH3wfTV/?Post:41

### ZeroTalk and ZeroMe Hubs

While the major features are decentralized, the user space limit management is centralized. There is a script somewhere that runs periodically (once a month or several months, I guess) and adds some space for every user who is about to run out of space.

I don't see the point in this approach.

A new user comes to the forum and quickly runs out of the default 50k. S/he tries to contact to @nofish, but no luck. S/he asks others, but no one can help them. So the new user concludes that ZeroNet is inconvenient and impractical.
S/he either leaves ZeroNet or decides to give it one more chance and registers another ID.
The second ID runs out of space as well.

Finally, after some suffering, if a user is persistent enough, s/he gets more space "for some reason". In fact, no reason, just a dumb script.

Why do we need that suffering part, and why not just give a user a default megabyte or so?
And why should we have this single point of failure at all?

The script doesn't solve any actual problems.
Spammers are still able to register lots of IDs, so the 50k limit is not a problem for them at all.
It's just ordinary users who are in trouble.

BTW, @gitcenter sucessfully tested the automated flood attack against this forum several years ago.

### ZeroSites

If you navigate to ZeroSites, you see that each zite has 2 numbers: "stars" and "peers". The latter is collected by a server and injected into the ZeroSites DB in the centralized way.
Zites are ordered by "popularity", which is `MIN(200, peers) + star * 20`.

Previously, the peer stats were updated every few hours. Now it's long broken. I [reported the issue](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroSites/issues/14), but no luck.

ZeroSites engine also has no check for the data relevance. As a workaround, if statistics have not been updated for a while, we can just ignore it. But that simple solution is not implemented.

A more sophisticated way is to make a new plugin for the core engine that integrates ZeroSites DB and Bootstrapper (peer tracker) DB. So any tracker with this plugin enabled can provide the actual stats. And a user chooses to trust it or not.

This stats problem doesn't look like a big issue, but it shows what may possibly happen if the server-side part of ZeroID or ZeroTalk goes down. Such flaws mustn't be present in a decentralized network.

### The default site list

It's not a centralization issue per se, but it adds some more problems to what described above.

When a new user installs ZeroNet, s/he sees a list of "default" zites in the left bar. The contents of this list is controlled by a single person and not by the community. I'm really not sure how this can be addressed, and if this should be addressed at all, but the infrastructure of ZeroNet is totally centralized and is ran by a single person.

topic.title: ZT++: now you can change the topic sorting order

Just a little announce of a little update of [ZT++](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EgyL4nj9DmeSSQg3fytxGJjihxtmMon5y/?Topic:1549373688_1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4/CHANGELOG+ZeroTalk+forum+engine).

If you use a forum engine to run a news site, it's often desirable to sort news by the news date itself, not by the date of the last comment. I added a simple configuration option, so now you can choose the sorting order: `last_activity` (default), `topic_creation`, `topic_author`, `comments_num`, `votes_num`.

I run [OpenNews 🇷🇺](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Nowr5oVEdbU5ZTQBriRd2jJVj2vhsDJd4/). You can see an example of using the sorting option there. The settings are in [content.json](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Nowr5oVEdbU5ZTQBriRd2jJVj2vhsDJd4/content.json).

By the way, previously I also added an option to adjust view of the topic list: brief (just a title of each topic), normal (the same as on ZeroTalk), long (formatted content, limited by height), full (formatted content fully). As you can see, the stickied topics are displayed as "brief" on OpenNews, and ordinary topics as "normal".

If you set topic_list_mode=full and topic_list_order_by=topic_creation, you may use the forum engine as a collective blog. The topic list will be displayed in a manner similar to what is normally used for blogs.

These settings are currently available to the zite owner only. I should add some UI for a visitor to be able to change these settings locally on the fly, but right now I'm too lazy to mess with HTML. I'm going to do this later...

topic.title: ZeroNet development? We need new heroes! We need you!
topic.body:
Hi, guys!

In November 2020, I had been working on a patch set for ZeroNet, but the lack of spare time did not allow me to bring the work to its logical conclusion.

Here is the change log draft of what has been done: https://github.com/zeronet-enhanced/ZeroNet/blob/massive-rework/ZNE-ChangeLog/ChangeLog-0.8.0.md

Now, when the upstream seems to be almost dead, it's time to join forces and make an actively developed fork. There are many wonderful patches and ideas here and there on the network, but we seem to have no place to commit them to any more. So we need to move on on our own.

If you have some dev skills and motivation, feel free to contact me. https://github.com/zeronet-enhanced/ is an organization profile, and I can add new devs as "members" or "owners" for the organization.

My primary goals/interests in developing ZeroNet are:

* Improving the stability.
* Fixing the connectivity and scalability issues.
* Implementing new transports, such as I2P. Or "sync over Freenet". Or maybe the offline update mode aka "sync this node from a USB flash stick".
* Bringing support of more crypto algorithms besides good old Bitcoin's elliptic curves.
* Implementing the multisign support of the root `content.json`: *right-way-this-time*. The current implementation is broken.
* Fixing various flaws in user-level muting/blocklisting.
* Implementing the darknet mode aka friend-2-friend mode, so one can use ZeroNet in a RetroShare-like manner.
* Bringing support of flexible zite-level control over user space limits etc, so zite policies may at some extent be scaled and controlled by its users, when the owner abandoned it.
* Implementing a declarative API that makes possible running a zite with dynamic AJAX updates and without executing an untrusted zite-level JS code in your browser. Running an untrusted code should be an option, not the core requirement.
* ...etc

Not my goals:

* Breaking things just because they are implemented "in a wrong way".
* Rewriting the engine in a shiny new programming language.

P.S. Related links:

* [\[BUG\] ZeroNet losts user data](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1616552733_1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4/+BUG+ZeroNet+losts+user+data)

UPD:

Since nofish is missing for long time, I cannot consider the mainline ZeroNet forum as secure any more. We have no clue where is nofish and where are his private keys. I assume the worst: the keys are in wrong hands and the zite may be erased at any time.

So I move all the important topics related to the development [to my forum](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1fznczNZUMEMvCiqSmCZGUiv5sVnRcsTD/).

topic.title: nofish implemented a misfeature for wiping inactive users (??!)
topic.body:
Folks, some controversial news...

### ISSUE 1

If you [look here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/data/users/content.json), you see the following data block:

```
 "user_contents": {
  "archived": {
   "1165u6pt5mQNFjyhMVwy6azB7bZuQGLA9b": 1523088096,
   "125b8FxS36xSSCHkvZEhimvF5KPxjckS7o": 1523088096,
   "127tNdRpqjPKrVbgYNJHyvHV2Hz43VApCK": 1523088097,
   "128SPB2TNDuT8sxcTRZ83BaN2T72c7QHDC": 1523088099,
   "128Vo1cvEvptz267w81cHfpqENkVUk8NXv": 1523088096,
   .
   .
   .
   LOTS OF IDS HERE
   .
   .
  },
  "archived_before": 1523088096,
```

What does this block mean? Here is what documentation says:

> `archived` - Delete the specified user content directory that is signed earlier than the specified timestamp (key: directory name, value: timestamp)
> `archived_before` - Delete all user content directory if that is signed earlier than the specified timestamp

My first thought was nofish made some script for moving old data into zite-controlled files to make free room for new posts in user files. But it doesn't seems to be the case. ZeroTalk has no additional data files besides user-provided ones.

Which means that any users that had no activity sinse `"archived_before": 1523088096`, i.e. **Apr 07 2018**, are erased from the forum. No posts, comments, likes, anything. Any topics that were created by those users, aren't accessible any more, even if those topics contain long and meaningful discussions.

What we can guess is that there is some script somewhere, that runs, or used to run, periodically and updates the `archived_before` field, wiping all the data of inactive users. We have no clue if the script is still active or not and when it gets activated the next time.

The only way to make sure your posts are safe is to visit the forum every few months and post/like anything in order to renew your activity status. Wow! Not sure about you guys, but for me it's definately not a thing I expect from a p2p storage that was designed to keep data almost forever. Correct me if I'm wrong, but this "feature" doesn't documented anywhere in the forum.

### ISSUE 2

The next level:

The misfeature was misused for banning users from the forum. You can ask, what happens if one assigns for a user an archivation date in the future? ZeroNet wipes the data and also refuses accepting and relaying user's data until the specified date in this case. And this means: a temporary ban.

Of cause one also can "archive" (ban) a user forever taking a date in a distant feature:
```
"128Vo1cvEvptz267w81cHfpqENkVUk8NXv": 9999999999
```

The latter is no news, since the ban can also be set up by user-space control policies. (No space -> no posts -> ban). But the old kind of ban is pretty straightforward: a user is either banned entirely or not. No temporarily ban is possible (at least, without additional scripts). So it is intended primarily for bots etc, and not for "punishing' users. The temporary ban opens up new opportunities for censorship.

I am not claiming that nofish applied the temporal ban for any user. It looks more like he used to block only bots. But he (or an owner of any zite) has the capability of doing that.

### OK, WHAT WE SHOULD DO?

My question is, is this "archivation" feature more for good or for evil? What should I do with it in my fork?

Keep it as is, since it can be used for implementing the real archivation of the user generated content?

Or disable it, as it can be easily misused intentionally or accidentally?

P.S.

Maybe "the depth of diving into the past" should be controlled by a user? User will have an option of choosing, if s/he wants to download a zite with the full history or from a selected date.

1549416429_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJV.body:
If you remove the permissions, all the user-generated data will be removed.
It is not a "freeze", but a kind of full reset.

The freezing procedure is kinda complicated.

If you want to keep all the user generated content, you should do the following steps (theoretically, I've never tested it) :

1. Find all `data/users/*/content.json`-s and resign each manually, using the site owner key.
2. Delete `data/users/content.json`.
3. Delete `data/users/content.json` from the `include` section of the root `content.json`.
4. Add all `data/users/*/content.json`-s to the `include` section.
5. Sign the root `content.json`

The purpose of those steps is to transfer the ownership of all the data under `data/users/*/*` from users to the site owner. So the files will be kept and not removed from the network, and at the same time, users cannot modify them.

Well, if you make some mistakes on any steps, the data will be lost.

**Edit: Modified the step 4. Looks like the initial idea was incorrect.**

> [kaffie](#comment_732_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Oh. Does the data get removed if you remove permissions? 

If you remove the permissions for the certificates, ZeroNet consider all the files that are signed by the certificates as invalid. Not sure if it removes them from the file system instantly, but for sure it stops transferring them over the network and displaying the content in the UI.

Well, looks like we need a feature to set the check-sum of the secondary `content.json`-s from the master one. That allows freezing the 3rd party data without the need to resign it under the master key.

But they'll say me again, that I'm trying to establish the censorship in the network.

> [leftside](#comment_524_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm): I'm just thinking of designing timestamp based hub system

One of the drawbacks of the nofish's archiving approach is the need of the central server, that archives the data on schedule. The timestamp based hub system probably solves that issue. 

The other approach I think of is the combination of optional and non-optional files, that is managed by a user (probably, automatically, by the forum software, not manually). New posts and comments are kept in non-optional `data.json` and old ones are moved to a set of optional `data-{timestamp}.json`-s. The non-optional limit can be set relatively small, and the optional one can be large (many gigabytes?).

A site visitor can set a limit, how old data files he/she wants to download in order to browse the old topics.

That approach requires no server and no need to connect new hubs. Users manage the data by themselves in transparent way.

> [xcape2net](#comment_50_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): If the domain name provider of my clearnet website decides to revoke my domain name in order to take down my site, then I just get a new domain name with another provider under a fake identity and put my site right back up with a new domain name. What's the point of a website that keeps being shut down over and over again? You consider it pure theoretically, and we have it in practice in Russia. Many popular websites were blocked in that way. Online libraries, opposition media etc. There's no point of a media that has no stable domain name, it is not visible by search engines and so on. Finally, the law now provides the conception of "forever ban" for a illegal site, so any copies on any domains are to be immediately blocked once noticed.

On the other hand, ZeroNet sites are addressed by bitcoin addresses, so that is pure math, and it cannot be banned by any government as long as they cannot ban math calculations. It is also not possible to shut down the hosting, since the site is hosted by a large number of users located all over the world in different jurisdictions. If at least one copy remains available, there again will be dozens of it soon.

ZeroNet provides the ability to keep the data potentially forever as well. It no longer matters that your hoster is down for some reason or you forgot to pay for the next month or your bank delayed the transaction. It also doesn't matter if you have lost interest in your websites, or hospitalized, or maybe you died, who knows. ([balancer73's zites still keep working six months after his death](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1BLoGBTid3NhGu8ts3fAfHJprnbrH3wfTV/?Post:45) and will probably work as long as we have any compatible browser to visit them.)

ZeroNet is also a kind of transport to be used in the poor connectivity conditions. Updates can be delayed for any time, but never lost and to be transmitted once the connection is possible. They can be transmitted via 3rt party peers by many hops, and finally you get them. ZeroNet-like network is probably the only possible kind of communication [in the deep space](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4/1549542994).

> [gitcenter](#comment_496_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): That will be changed a little. I.e., the site owner will be able to send a request to mark that the site is now multisign-only. After that, the master key is invalidated.

To send a request *where*? To `content.json`?

Just imagine a situation:

I send `content.json` (to several peers), that claims the zite should be signed by keys *A, B, C* from now, and a millisecond later I send `content.json` (to another set of peers), that claims the zite should be signed by keys *D, E, F*.

Okay, now we have 2 incompatible versions of the zite, with different content and different signers. Peers are splitted into 2 camps: who seed the first one and who seed the second one; and each camp considers the other camp's version as "wrong".

That's not a sound solution. As I said in the previous discussions, bitcoin addresses are pure math, so we can trust them in the same way as we can trust arithmetic operations. There's no blockchain, web-of-trust, a certificate authority etc, which all are human-dependent solutions and can be hacked in various ways. That's great. And I'd like to keep that greatness.

Just few days ago, the similar idea was discussed on a Russian Linux forum in the clearnet.

My thoughts on ZeroMe design:

* The registry address shouldn't be hard-coded in the engine sources. Registries can be added dynamically via the merger feature.
  * In order to support various user ID providers and possible future extensions of the core design.
* The existing collective hubs should be used as a cache to keep recent entries.
  * There also may be thematic hubs, similar to user groups and communities in the clearnet social networking apps.
* Each user has their own personal hub.
* When you post a message, it lands to your personal hub as well as to any number of collective hubs, at your choice.
* An owner of a collective hub can ban you or censor you, but since there will be thousands of collective hubs run by different people, it's practically impossible to ban you from the network entirely.
* An even if you're banned from a hub, people, who has been subscribed to your personal hub, are still able to read your posts.
* Comments and likes aren't necessary to be saved at the same hub, as the original post. (That's required in the current design.) They can be merged from different hubs. Again, to prevent censorship. And also, to make possible merging different user ID providers and engine extensions. A reader can choose in the settings, if s/he follows the censorship policy of the post author, or prefers merging comments from various sources regargdless of the author's hub config.

> [styromaniac](#comment_1939_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): I kept hearing that Tor peers are necessary to publish unless you have an opened port.

If you don't use Tor and you are behind NAT, the publishing can be tricky:

* Find some volunteer peers with port open. http://127.0.0.1:43110/1LtvsjbtQ2tY7SCtCZzC4KhErqEK3bXD4n/ can be helpful to find some peers. You can also use public proxies, if they have port open.
* These peers go to trackers to find your peer, but they are not able to connect to you through NAT. However, they register themselves at the trackers.
* Now you open your site and publish some data or just sign content.json from the sidebar.
* Your host is trying to push the updates to some peers, so it requests the peer list from trackers.
* Since your volunteer peers have port open, your host succesfully connects and sends the data.
* Now you can publish any updates, and visitors can access your site, connecting to volunteer peers.
* If volunteer peers go offline or remove your site from the storage, connectivity is broken and you have to find some others.

So, generally speaking it's better to always run Tor to avoid those troubles.
